data.title: Trading Update
data.full_content:
20 Nov 2024 07:00
RNS Number : 8682M
Knights Group Holdings PLC
20 November 2024
Knights Group Holdings plc
("Knights", the "Company" or the "Group")
Trading update for the six months ended 31 October 2024
Strong margin improvement, revolving credit facility extended
Confident in delivering a FY performance in line with market expectations
Knights, the national legal and professional services business, today provides a trading update for the six months ended 31 October 2024.
The Group has delivered a strong performance in the period with underlying PBT1 expected to increase by 25.9% to c.£14.6m (H1 24: £11.6m), on anticipated revenue growth of 5.4% to c.£79.4m (H1 24: £75.3m). This reflects a 3.0% pts increase in PBT margin to 18.4% (H1 24: 15.4%) and continued strong progression from 12.6% in H1 23. This strong first half performance underscores the Group's confidence in delivering a full year performance in line with market expectations.
In September 2024, the Group acquired Thursfields Legal Limited, a full legal services business with a national client base, significantly strengthening Knights' presence in the West Midlands. The business is integrating well, and is performing in line with expectations.
Momentum in recruitment continues, with 23 senior professionals joining Knights in the first half (H1 24: 20) and a good pipeline of further hires for the second half, driven by increased brand awareness and a growing reputation across the UK legal services market.
Balance sheet and Extended Revolving Credit Facility
The Group's continued strong focus on working capital discipline is reflected in debtor days2 at 31 October 2024 of 33 (H1 24: 31 days)
. Net debt3 was £50.1m at 31 October 2024, (at 30 April 2024 : £35.2m) after paying £8.9m initial and deferred consideration in respect of acquisitions.
The Group has agreed with HSBC UK, AIB (GB) and NatWest to extend its revolving credit facility to provide total committed funding of £100m (an increase from the existing £70m) until November 2027 (extended by a year). The extended facility provides the Group with significant headroom to execute its
value-accretive acquisition strategy as suitable opportunities arise.
UK national insurance
The changes announced in the UK Government's Autumn Budget on 30 October, and primarily the changes to national insurance contributions, are expected to have an annualised cost impact of £2m in FY 26, with just one month of the changes impacting FY 25. The Group is well-positioned in relation to these changes through its ongoing focus on growth, efficiency and pricing.
David Beech, CEO of Knights, commented:
"It has been a strong first half and I am particularly pleased with our focus on profitable revenue growth. The continued improvement in margin reflects the increasing quality of our revenue, team and our continued focus on the cost base.
"We are encouraged by our strong momentum in recruitment which continues to build as Knights' national scale and strong reputation are increasingly recognised. These factors, together with our ongoing focus on operational excellence, and early signs of a recovery in corporate and residential housing work, position us well for a strong performance in the second half in line with market expectations."
Knights will provide a further update on trading with its half year results announcement on 14 January 2025.
Ends
Notes
1
Underlying PBT is before amortisation of acquired intangibles, non-underlying operating expenses, and non-underlying finance costs. Non-underlying operating expenses include transaction and onerous lease expenses in relation to acquisitions, contingent acquisition payments, disposal of acquired assets, along with one-off restructuring staff and professional expenses, mainly incurred on acquisitions, through streamlining support functions or strategic reorganisations.
2
Debtor days are calculated on a count back basis using the gross debtors at the period end and compared with total fees raised over prior months.
3
Net debt includes cash and cash equivalents, borrowings and acquired debt but excludes lease liabilities.

data.title: AGM Statement
data.full_content:
24 Sep 2024 07:00
RNS Number : 3053F
Knights Group Holdings PLC
24 September 2024
Knights Group Holdings plc
("Knights", the "Company" or the "Group")
Annual General Meeting
Knights today holds its Annual General Meeting at 10:30am on 24 September 2024 at Riverside Court, Wilmslow, Cheshire, SK9 1DL.
At the AGM, the Group's Chairman, Dave Wilson, will make the following remarks:
"Knights delivered a good financial performance for the last financial year with underlying PBT
1
growth of 17% against a challenging market backdrop. This performance reflected the strength of our diversified service offering, and continued execution against our strategy, and built on our strong track record of profitable growth."
"Our unique culture continues to be a differentiator for us in the UK legal market and a key driver of our momentum in attracting new talent, through both recruitment and acquisition. This underpins the Board's confidence in the current year."
Further details can be found on Knights' website:
https://www.knightsplc.com/investors
Footnotes
1
Underlying PBT is before amortisation of acquired intangibles, non-underlying operating expenses, and non-underlying finance costs. Non-underlying operating expenses include transaction and onerous lease expenses in relation to acquisitions, contingent acquisition payments, disposal of acquired assets, along with one-off restructuring staff and professional expenses, mainly incurred on acquisitions, through streamlining support functions or strategic reorganisations.
Contingent acquisition payments are treated as a non-underlying expense as this represents payments for acquisitions which are dependent on the continued employment of certain individuals in the business for an agreed contractual period after an acquisition of one to three years to preserve the acquired goodwill and customer relationships. Accounting standards require such arrangements to be treated as remuneration in the Statement of Comprehensive Income. However, the individuals also receive market rate salaries, therefore, if not separately identified, these payments would significantly distort the reported results.
Ends

data.title: Acquisition of Thursfields Legal Limited
data.full_content:
26 Jul 2024 07:00
RNS Number : 9163X
Knights Group Holdings PLC
26 July 2024
Knights Group Holdings plc
("Knights" or the "Group")
Acquisition of Thursfields Legal Limited
Significantly strengthens West Midlands presence
Knights today announces that it has agreed to acquire Thursfields Legal Limited (trading as "Thursfields" and "Thursfields Solicitors"), a premium, full service legal services business with offices across the West Midlands.
Acquisition rationale and background
Founded in 1878, Thursfields is an independent, full-service regional law firm with offices in Worcester, Kidderminster, Solihull and Birmingham. Since inception, Thursfields has transformed from a traditional law firm into a corporatised, premium provider of legal services to a national client base.
The firm has a strong Private Wealth offering, spanning Private Client, Family and Residential Property, alongside Corporate, Real Estate and Dispute Resolution services. The acquisition sees 101 fee earning professionals join Knights and significantly strengthens the Group's presence in the West Midlands.
The acquisition is well-aligned with Knights' strategy to bolster its future organic growth through selective, considered acquisitions. It further extends Knights' existing capabilities in Private Wealth, while bringing a high-quality team and national client base, which will benefit from Knights' wider range of services and its established platform.
In its unaudited accounts for the year ended 30 April 2024, Thursfields reported revenue of £11.2m and a PBT margin of circa 25%. Following full integration and realisation of synergies, the Board expects it to contribute a PBT margin of circa 30%
.
Accounting for a typical level of revenue attrition post-acquisition, the acquisition is expected to be immediately earnings enhancing.
Terms of the acquisition
Under the terms of the acquisition, Knights will acquire
Thursfields Legal Limited from its ten shareholders on a debt free, cash free basis, for a total consideration of c.£12.5m. This comprises initial cash consideration of c.£7.5m and deferred cash consideration of £5.0m to be paid in three equal instalments on each of the first, second and third anniversaries following completion. The cash consideration will be satisfied from Knights' existing banking facilities. Completion is expected to take place on 14 September 2024.
Commenting on the acquisition, David Beech, CEO of Knights, said:
"We are delighted to acquire Thursfields, a premium, full-service law firm which shares many cultural and operational similarities to Knights, and significantly strengthens our position as a leading legal and professional services business in the Midlands.
"With particular strength in Private Wealth, it further enhances our expertise in an important and growing part of our business, which will support our future growth plans.
Michelle O'Hara, Managing Partner at Thursfields commented:
"Knights is a business with a similar ethos to Thursfields, with a strong culture which cultivates collaboration across its offices, to the benefit of client service.
"We look forward to working closely with the team and leveraging Knights' scale, reputation and extensive capabilities, to unlock our future growth potential."
- ENDS -

data.title: Full Year Results
data.full_content:
8 Jul 2024 07:00
RNS Number : 4057V
Knights Group Holdings PLC
08 July 2024
Knights Group Holdings plc
("Knights" or the "Group")
Full Year Results
A good performance, reflecting resilience, scale and financial discipline
Plan to double the business in medium term
Knights, the legal and professional services business, today announces its full year results for the year ended 30 April 2024.
Financial highlights
·
Revenue increased by 6% to £150m (FY23: £142.1m); organic growth of 1.9%
·
Gross margin of 48.8% (FY23: 48.5%)
·
Underlying PBT1 up 17.3% to £25.3m (FY23: £21.6m); underlying PBT1 margin increased to 16.9% (FY23: 15.2%)
·
Reported PBT increased 28.6% to £14.8m (FY23: £11.5m)
·
Underlying EPS2 increased
8% to 21.81p (FY23: 20.20p). Basic EPS of 11.47p (FY23: 9.28p)
·
Strong improvement in lock up3 days to 78 (FY23: 87 days), with debtor days improving to 28 (FY23: 30 days)
·
Continued excellent cash conversion4 of 131% (FY23: 117%) enabling investment in growth
·
Net debt5 of £35.2m (30 April 23: £29.2m), after a cash outlay of £11.3m relating to acquisitions and a joint venture investment in Convex
Corporate Finance Limited
resulting in a reduction in banking covenant EBITDA / net debt ratio to 1.1x (30 April 2023: 1.2x)
·
Final dividend of 2.79p (FY23: 2.50p), giving a 9% increase in the total dividend to 4.40p (FY23: 4.03p)
Strategic and operational highlights
A good performance as we strengthened our platform for growth
·
40 senior fee earners joined the business (FY23: 27), as awareness increases of our national scale, differentiated model, and strong culture. Strong retention with 12% churn (FY23: 18%)
·
Won a number of new and significant clients and extended our relationships with a number of existing clients
·
Continued focus on cost discipline and operational excellence
Increased scale and diversification through considered acquisitions and partnerships
·
Acquired Baines Wilson and St James Law in the period, both are trading ahead of expectations and provide strong platforms for future organic growth; seven senior recruits have joined these new offices since acquisition
·
Formed a joint venture with Convex, diversifying our range of services further, with its entrepreneur focus bringing synergies with our corporate and private wealth offering
Current trading and Outlook
·
Encouraging start to the year with a strong recovery in residential property
·
Focused on client acquisition and deeper collaboration across offices to bring more services to existing clients
·
Sustained recruitment momentum and good retention
·
Active pipeline of attractive acquisitions
·
Confident of delivering a meaningful improvement in organic growth in the current financial year
Plan to double the business in the medium term
·
Execution of strategy and market tailwinds to drive revenue and profit growth
·
Expected to be delivered through strong organic growth complemented by our value accretive acquisition strategy
·
Builds on considerable growth to date, EBITDA more than quadrupled since IPO in 2018
David Beech, CEO of Knights, commented:
"Knights has delivered a good performance against a challenging market backdrop, reflecting the strength of our diversified service offering, and continued execution against our strategy, and building on our strong track record of profitable growth since IPO in 2018.
"We have diversified our service offering, won a number of new clients, sharpened our focus on operational excellence and made considered strategic acquisitions, bolstering our scale in the North, an important region.
"This progress, together with an encouraging start to the year, including a strong recovery in residential property, in line with our expectations, means we are confident in delivering our ambitions plans to double the size of the business in the medium term."
Footnotes
1
Underlying PBT is before amortisation of acquired intangibles, non-underlying operating expenses, and non-underlying finance costs. Non-underlying operating expenses include transaction and onerous lease expenses in relation to acquisitions, contingent acquisition payments, disposal of acquired assets, along with one-off restructuring staff and professional expenses, mainly incurred on acquisitions, through streamlining support functions or strategic reorganisations.
Contingent acquisition payments are treated as a non-underlying expense as this represents payments for acquisitions which are dependent on the continued employment of certain individuals in the business for an agreed contractual period after an acquisition of one to three years to preserve the acquired goodwill and customer relationships. Accounting standards require such arrangements to be treated as remuneration in the Statement of Comprehensive Income. However, the individuals also receive market rate salaries, therefore, if not separately identified, these payments would significantly distort the reported results.
2
Underlying EPS is underlying PAT divided by the weight

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Been holding these a while and have done fairly well - surprised to see the negativity on this board about this stock. It went from very loved to very hated back in 2022 - seems to me the reality is somewhere in between. I like the model, like the market and think mgmt have a good track record of creating value over the long term here (and yes also creating value for themselves). Think due a FY trading update in a couple of weeks. And have done two reasonably decent deals so far in FY25 (ie after the march year end) which should drive some upgrades to FY26 and beyond, but also will increase debt I guess (although not for the FY results coming). And yes more deferred consideration, but that is the model here and deferred consideration is better than paying all upfront in cash (as no interest cost!). Gateley's results were cautiously positive, with 3% organic growth, so hopefully Knights can get to around that level. M&A seems to have picked up a bit which should help and I think property market has also improved a little which might also help. Also will be watching capex spend - it was very high in FY24 and FY25 as they undertook a big office refit programme, so hoping this comes down materially in their guidance for FY26 although we might not get that much detail until their FY results I guess around July time.... I think this is still very cheap for what you get here. Quality business and decent long term growth story in a defensive sector. I think its trading on about 5.8x PE! Or about 6.5x EV/EBIT even if you treat all the deferred consideration as debt. Can argue those are about 50% too cheap at least. I no expert on the technical side of things but to my untrained eye the chart looks pretty good at the moment also?

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: I think the IPO was at 145p back in 2018? And share capital back then was c.73m vs 86m today as they did a placing to fund some acquisitions. But the business is more than 3x the size in both revenue and profit terms now, so they have more than tripled the size of the business whilst only increasing the share count by less than 20%. This is basically the proof that their M&A model works and is generally funded by cashflow from the underlying business (and not by issuing shares / dilution) and drives value over the long term even if it means the balance sheet will always have a bit of debt and deferred consideration lingering on it. Not sure I can get to 500p unless there is a very generous acquirer, but with a bit of organic growth, some more bolt on deals, and rerating to eg 12x PE (not crazy in my books) I can see 350-400p in the medium term. CEO still owns north of 20% of the company so is pretty well aligned with shareholders here I think, even if he has sold a bunch and made a lot of money already.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Gateley results read fairly well today, organic growth 4%, decent outlook statement although wary of macro volatility... Gateley trades on about 7.8x EV/EBIT. Back in the day it always used to trade on a discount to Knights, but not any more. By my numbers Knights is on about 6.9X EV/EBIT, so a 10-15% discount to Gateley... - Mcap 165m - Net debt 65m + 10m for recent Birket Long deal = £75m. Less maybe £5m cash generated = £70m - Deferred consideration about £7m + £6m from Birkett Long deal = £13m - EV 165 + 70 + 13 = £250m ish Consensus Adj PBT for FY26 = £32m Plus maybe £4m interest = EBIT of £36m EV/EBIT = 250/36 = 6.9x If KGH rerated to GTLY rating, it would imply about 20% upside, ie about 230p. But I think -GTLY should be more highly rated. It's not the most exciting business but is a consistent performer that has proven resilience through the cycle -KGH should trade at a premium, as it has done historically, due to its higher growth proven buy and build model - I also think over time the upside from degearing the balance sheet will also be material which is less a factor for Gateley Still see a route to 300p+ on these in the short-medium term.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: According to London Stock Exchange website, trades were going through at 180p+ until about 3.50pm. And then after that there were a number of bigger trades that went through and over the last 40 mins of trading that drove the price down. But not massive trades, it looks like less than 100k shares in total, which isn't much in the context of a £160m mcap business. But I'm guessing there may be more selling to come behind that, hence the drop. But (in the absence of any actual news) seems to be the classic illiquid microcap getting hit disproportionately by pretty marginal selling. On twitter / X there is some healthy debate around the buy and build model (which I am comfortable with having looked at in detail, and think builds value long term), the debt levels (again I'm comfortable) and the weak backdrop in UK legal services (fair point but think overstated given GTLY today and last trading statement). I think some folk underestimate the cashflow the underlying business generates, especially with capex due to come down materially now their office refit is complete. Either one should take into account the significant growth the buy and build model generates, whilst critiquing the use of cash for M&A. OR one should consider the organic growth which is much more modest - but in this case look at underlying cash generation excl M&A. Some people out there penalise this stock BOTH for the spend on M&A, AND whilst criticising the stock for low growth excluding M&A - overly harsh in my view. But anyway this debate has been on going for a while, couldn't find anything new today... Lets see what tomorrow brings...

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: F15: How do you figure / calculate organic growth being negative? Overall they've said they'll do £162m this year vs £150 last year. Y/E is end April 2025. Of the incremental £12m I make from M&A: - IBB Law, approx c.£2m (less than 1 month of the reported £23m revenue). Completed early April 2025 - Thrusfields, approx c.£7m (7.5 months of reported £11.2m revenue). Completed mid Sept 2024 - St James Law and Baines Wilson c.£1m (maybe 2 months of reported £6.5, revenue). Not sure when completed but announce early May 2023, ie 10-11 months will fall in FY24, so only an incremental 1-2 months in FY25 vs FY24 - Convex JV is small and accounted for using equity method, ie the revenues won't be consolidated so not applicable to revenue calculations AFAIK So I make about £10m incremental revenue max from M&A in FY25, with about £2m from organic growth. Which is 1-2% organic growth. Actually it should be higher than this, as they normally expect about 20% revenue churn from new acquisitions (and they state this), so it may be more like £8m from M&A and £4m from organic growth, ie 2-3% organic growth. I'd say 'modest' is probably an appropriate term to describe this level of growth. For FY26 they are currently forecast to do £193m revenue, which is £31m incremental to FY25. Similar logic says: - £21m from IBB Law, £4m from Thursfield max. £25m total - Birket Long maybe £12.5m incremental (completion mid June 2025, total annual revenue £14.7m) Total incremental from M&A of £37m, which does imply a reduction of max £5-6m. BUT applying similar 20% revenue churn to M&A, it gets you to £30m from M&A and again a £1-2m incremental from organic. They do actually say in the RNS about Birkett Long that it brings their annualised revenue to 'over £200m' which possibly implies forecasts for FY26 are a little conservative currently and would imply continued 3% ish organic growth... The announcement was in May so of course it assumes things haven't got a chunk worse in the month or two since then. On debt, they will have about £75m net debt currently after Birkett Long payment, vs forecast £48.5m EBITDA for FY26. ie leverage of about 1.5x; still a decent amount of headroom, and they will generate cash through the year, especially now their office refit is complete. Happy to be taken to task on any of the above! Of course I'd love organic growth to be higher, and think it will be when macro environment improves. But, respectfully, I don't think you are characterising the business correctly in terms of both the growth profile and the level of debt.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Doesn't take into account the 20% churn they expect from acquisitions. I think since listing they have had one year of negative organic growth (-3% FY21, ie Covid, creditable performance IMHO), and one year of flat growth (-0.1% in FY23); the rest have shown organic growth. Admittedly the growth rate is lower today compared to the double digit organic growth they were doing pre-covid; but of course you need to take into account the weaker economic backdrop. They also exited some smaller non-core activities in 2023 (and probably at other points also). My view is the organic growth will pick up when the economic backdrop improves as M&A work and residential property work has been subdued now for a while. And besides, that they've tripled their revenues and profits since listing, whilst only increasing their share count by about 15%, is good evidence their buy and build model works... Net debt is only up about £60m (£15m to £75m) over that time, whilst EBITDA is up about £37m (£48m FY26 vs £11m in FY19). And they've been paying a divi over that period also. Hey ho, different views are what makes a market I guess...

data.author: f15jcm
data.content: The comment about churn aside (they dont allow for this in the multiples thy claim to have paid for acquisitions), you present a good counter argument. I did make money owning this share but sold out a while ago, partly due to their treatment of interest on client monies. It has gone up since I sold, so well done to those that held on. I'll certainly be looking for signs of trouble in future updates and wouldn't be inclined to give management the benefit of any doubt with debt where it is.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: TBH I agree with you in general about buy and builds, and you are right to ask the question re organic growth and debt (and interest income). I'm comfortable on all these points. Would argue the unravelling has already happened with this stock back in 2022 when it went from 400p to 150p. It was a) overrated and b) getting too much credit for the buy and build model and c) traded on a big premium to Gateley. As I've argued I think the opposite is true now at the current valuation on all three fronts. I'm up a fair chunk on my holding even after the pull back in the last few days, but think there is still a lot more to go for. In due course I suspect the CEO will want out, and suspect this will be taken private. Private Equity loves a buy and build, and will value the consistency of their revenues / cash generation more than the lack of high organic growth.

data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: "An attractive and undervalued regional consolidator" - initiation report freely accessible here: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/an-attractive-and-undervalued-regional-consolidator Knights’ FY25 results illustrate the power of its business model to attract high-quality legal professionals across the UK, both organically and through selective acquisitions. FY25 revenues rose 8% to £162m, with operating leverage driving Adj. PBT up 11% and margin up 40bps to 17.3%. Investment in offices and acquisitions, along with encouraging current trading, underpins our forecasts for profitable growth. Yet the stock is trading on only c.5x cal 2026 PER and hence the shares are well below our 230p fair value. We also examine the strength of its differentiated “corporatised law” business model. As an active consolidator in the premium regional legal market, Knights has funded over 20 acquisitions in the past 12 years, culminating in group revenues rising 8% to £162m in FY25 and £200m+ in FY26E (a 13-year CAGR of 27%). Good pricing discipline and a focus on operational excellence has seen average revenues per fee-earner rise 12% and underlying PBT margins rose 40bps to 17.3%. In our view, Knights offers a compelling mix of organic and acquisitive growth. Yet, its valuation is at a significant discount to peers and its historic trading range. Trading on only c.5x cal 2026 PER and offering a c.16% cal FCF yield (pre-acquisitions) we see scope for a significant rerating.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Organic growth lacklustre in FY25 for sure, although FY25 was in line, and forecasts maintained for FY26 which is good news. Equity Dev are forecasting 5% organic growth for the coming year though, and a few things pointing to better performance here - better recruitment and retention of fee earners, and organically are opening an office in Cardiff which I don't think they have done previously. And they're basically 5 months into FY26 already given the late release of results, so they should have decent visibility of trading ytd already... Did anyone listen to the investor call? Not on their website yet... I still think the valuation here is silly, even given the lack of growth last year. FY28 forecasts are for £47m operating profit, and will have paid off essentially all contingent consideration by then, so net debt will be about £55m. Should be trading at 7-8x EBIT in my view (v conservatively), which would be EV £330-375m, Mcap of £275-320m, and share price at least double where we are now. Plus a 3-4% divi yield while you wait...

data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: "Delivering on its strategic ambitions" - new research with video summary freely accessible here: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/delivering-on-its-strategic-ambitions Knights’ H126 trading update illustrates the power of its position as the leading consolidator in the premium, regional legal market. Knights’ H126 revenues rose an impressive 30% to £103.2m as a return to organic growth of 3% was complemented by the recent strategic acquisitions of IBB Law, Birkett Long, Rix & Kay and Le Gros Solicitors. These acquisitions are all integrating well, with working capital benefits coming through under Knights’ ownership. From this strong performance, management is confident in achieving FY26E expectations. Whilst Knights’ share price has risen 16% in the past two months, it still only trades on 6x cal 2026 PER, a significant discount to peers and its historic trading range. In our view, Knights offers a compelling mix of organic and acquisitive growth, with net financial debt / EBITDA only 1.4x (FY26E). We see scope for a significant rerating and reiterate our 230p/ share fair value estimate.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: This has dropped back c.20% from the highs now. Not sure why other than market malaise? Trading update last week showed everything is still in line and despite the uncertainty around the budget etc the business is still growing and performing as expected. As ever would hope organic growth improves from 3% in H1 to the 5% that they guided to for the full year a short time ago... This is now trading on 5.8x EV/EBIT, 6.4 PE, for a growing business that is performing well and that throws off cash. Although net debt has increased, they have paid off a substantial amount of deferred consideration in the last few years, as of now only £17m ish remains. Balance sheet well below 2x geared now. Interesting to think that in 2021 this share was trading at 400p ish. It's now less than half that, despite revenue (£100m to £200m) and operating profit (£20m to 40m) having doubled in the period since... I still think this gets to 320-370p over the next 2-3 years - and that's not assuming anything other than hitting their forecasts and a modest rerating to 7-8x EV/EBIT. Plus you'll get 16p+ in dividends over that period. I actually think this could prove pretty conservative as in reality they will continue to acquire / integrate businesses and will be bigger / more profitable than forecasts currently suggest by that point in time...

data.content: Gateley H1 (to end Oct) showed organic growth of 10.9% in legal services. Shows it can be done even in this market. Knights cand and should be growing faster organically than it is. We expect this inertia to unwind in H2". SO this implies another 3% organic growth which should be deferred to H2. data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: "Successful strategy deserves a higher rating" - link to (freely accessible) new research here: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/successful-strategy-deserves-a-higher-rating Knights’ H126 results were as announced at its update in November and illustrate the power of its position as the leading consolidator in the premium, regional legal market. Revenues rose an impressive 30%, including a return to organic growth of 2.6%, and Adj. PBT rose 12.5%, despite absorbing increased national insurance costs and investing in AI, led by a new CTO. Operating cashflow conversion has been excellent and momentum has continued into H226, hence management is confident in achieving FY26E expectations. Yet Knights still only trades on 6.5x cal 2026 PER and under 6x cal 2027 PER. Given the successful H126 and positive outlook we raise our Fair Value/per share from 230p to 255p, equivalent to c.8x cal 2027 PER.
data.thread_title: "Successful strategy deserves a higher rating" - new research

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Solid results, no real surprises to the upside or down. Looks like they might be marginally ahead of expectations for FY on rev / profit, and maybe will beat on cash / debt. Organic growth at 3% when it should really be higher, expecting 5% for the full year so H2 should be better but they didn't give anything quantitative about H2 trading other than that it was building on momentum and in line with expectations. Gateley growing faster organically, proves it can be done if mgmt get it right. Hopefully the lower staff churn and new recruits will start to deliver and we'll see an acceleration. As ever there are a few wrinkles - high exceptionals in the period (M&A related), organic growth a bit low (see above) but importantly is positive number now, capex still higher than where it should be in my view for this sort of business given they have finished their refurb programme now, and margins trajectory could be better but mainly impacted by things outside their control. Having said that I still think this business is an absolute steal at 6.5x PE. Hoping that they have an H2 without any M&A so that there is a clean period of organic growth, cash generation and deleveraging of the balance sheet. Only 3.5 months left in their FY, so they should have high visibility to the FY numbers, and can get on to the front foot for FY27 come April. Organic growth plus stabilisation / improvement of margins, plus cash generation plus a few more sensible deals... And sentiment to this could finally begin to turn more positive; rerating to 8-10x PE is eminently achievable to my mind in the near term - 240-300p. 12x would not be an outrageous rating to expect on continued delivery, which would be 350-400p longer term.

data.author: Dartron
data.content: I sold my Knights shares before and after the results, after a fantastic 30% rise over Christmas. https://x.com/DartronTrading/status/1745407668406173818?s=20 I just felt that there wasn't anything left in the tank from a rally perspective. I bought another small cap, which is in the position that Knights was around a year ago. Well under half of its fair value, still recovering from a few recent issues. I think that is what attracted me to Knights, being able to buy as low as the 70's. with a 50% upside. I note there was a lot more discussion on this board back at that time, have most sold out as well? I was prompted to post here today as I found this rating from Shore capital, which has a target price of 115p - and yes it was published after the latest results. TBH, I would like to buy these back, but Im not interested in paying above 115 for them after ExD. The Investors Chronical also rates these as a hold and has them on a PE of 11, which disagrees somewhat with Shore's PE of 5 even taking in to account the rise in SP. The shore article is a little contradictory expecting the shares to re rate, but the price is already above their fair value target.  I can see the 115 target on the research portal of IC, so its not a typo. The median target here is 160. I have shares that have dropped on weak earnings with higher % targets than this after they have been down graded - AFM today for example, "Analyst Calum Battersby retained his ‘buy’ recommendation and target price of 420p on the consultancy group" that is a 25% upside target after a downgrade. All makes me thinks Knights is around fair value, and not much of an income play. (AFM is not my new small cap, im stuck in there over a year). Shore Capital makes a strong case for resilient Knights Group Legal services company Knights Group (KGH) is trading on an ‘undemanding’ valuation and has scope to rerate, says Shore Capital. Analyst Jamie Murray retained his ‘buy’ recommendation and ‘fair value’ target price of 115p on the stock, which was trading at 121p on Friday. It reported ‘resilient’ first half 2024 results, which ‘highlighted that management is executing its renewed strategy to focus on organic growth’, Murray said. ‘The outlook is positive with non-cyclical legal activity showing resilience and recruitment initiatives increasing fee earner headcount,’ he explained. Although Knights is a ‘well-regarded law firm with as strong presence outside of London which enables it to win market share’, Murray said the shares trade on an ‘undemanding price/earnings target of 5x’. ‘We expect this to increase following these resilient results,’ he said. ‘If management continue to execute its new strategy focused on organic growth, we think it can rerate to a multiple more in-line with the sector.’

Revenue increased by 6% to £150m (FY23: £142.1m); organic growth of 1.9% · Gross margin of 48.8% (FY23: 48.5%) · Underlying PBT1 up 17.3% to £25.3m (FY23: £21.6m); underlying PBT1 margin increased to 16.9% (FY23: 15.2%) · Reported PBT increased 28.6% to £14.8m (FY23: £11.5m) · Underlying EPS2 increased 8% to 21.81p (FY23: 20.20p). Basic EPS of 11.47p (FY23: 9.28p) · Strong improvement in lock up3 days to 78 (FY23: 87 days), with debtor days improving to 28 (FY23: 30 days) · Continued excellent cash conversion4 of 131% (FY23: 117%) enabling investment in growth · Net debt5 of £35.2m (30 April 23: £29.2m), after a cash outlay of £11.3m relating to acquisitions and a joint venture investment in Convex Corporate Finance Limited resulting in a reduction in banking covenant EBITDA / net debt ratio to 1.1x (30 April 2023: 1.2x) · Final dividend of 2.79p (FY23: 2.50p), giving a 9% increase in the total dividend to 4.40p (FY23: 4.03p)

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Been holding these a while and have done fairly well - surprised to see the negativity on this board about this stock. It went from very loved to very hated back in 2022 - seems to me the reality is somewhere in between. I like the model, like the market and think mgmt have a good track record of creating value over the long term here (and yes also creating value for themselves). Think due a FY trading update in a couple of weeks. And have done two reasonably decent deals so far in FY25 (ie after the march year end) which should drive some upgrades to FY26 and beyond, but also will increase debt I guess (although not for the FY results coming). And yes more deferred consideration, but that is the model here and deferred consideration is better than paying all upfront in cash (as no interest cost!). Gateley's results were cautiously positive, with 3% organic growth, so hopefully Knights can get to around that level. M&A seems to have picked up a bit which should help and I think property market has also improved a little which might also help. Also will be watching capex spend - it was very high in FY24 and FY25 as they undertook a big office refit programme, so hoping this comes down materially in their guidance for FY26 although we might not get that much detail until their FY results I guess around July time.... I think this is still very cheap for what you get here. Quality business and decent long term growth story in a defensive sector. I think its trading on about 5.8x PE! Or about 6.5x EV/EBIT even if you treat all the deferred consideration as debt. Can argue those are about 50% too cheap at least. I no expert on the technical side of things but to my untrained eye the chart looks pretty good at the moment also?

Like you I see significant upside as this stock hit 480 in 2021 and was substantially less profitable than today. The CEO David Beech is the founder and still the largest shareholder with 17M shares. Beech sold 15.7M shares when Knights floated at 390 per share and pocketed 61.8M Professional Services is a hot sector for Private Equity who have been very active in the Accounting arena. I think the only way Beech can cash in for another big number is either a Sale to PE or a Merger with one of the USA players. I'm thinking 500 !!

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: I think the IPO was at 145p back in 2018? And share capital back then was c.73m vs 86m today as they did a placing to fund some acquisitions. But the business is more than 3x the size in both revenue and profit terms now, so they have more than tripled the size of the business whilst only increasing the share count by less than 20%. This is basically the proof that their M&A model works and is generally funded by cashflow from the underlying business (and not by issuing shares / dilution) and drives value over the long term even if it means the balance sheet will always have a bit of debt and deferred consideration lingering on it. Not sure I can get to 500p unless there is a very generous acquirer, but with a bit of organic growth, some more bolt on deals, and rerating to eg 12x PE (not crazy in my books) I can see 350-400p in the medium term. CEO still owns north of 20% of the company so is pretty well aligned with shareholders here I think, even if he has sold a bunch and made a lot of money already.

data.content: Bearish RSI chart indicator where RSI made a lower recent  high peak, while the sp made a higher recent peak. Using the first RSI peak as the pivot, implies the sp could fall to between 152.5-157. Also the sp usually completes a three leg movement in a retracement, before completion of the movement. data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Gateley results read fairly well today, organic growth 4%, decent outlook statement although wary of macro volatility... Gateley trades on about 7.8x EV/EBIT. Back in the day it always used to trade on a discount to Knights, but not any more. By my numbers Knights is on about 6.9X EV/EBIT, so a 10-15% discount to Gateley... - Mcap 165m - Net debt 65m + 10m for recent Birket Long deal = £75m. Less maybe £5m cash generated = £70m - Deferred consideration about £7m + £6m from Birkett Long deal = £13m - EV 165 + 70 + 13 = £250m ish Consensus Adj PBT for FY26 = £32m Plus maybe £4m interest = EBIT of £36m EV/EBIT = 250/36 = 6.9x If KGH rerated to GTLY rating, it would imply about 20% upside, ie about 230p. But I think -GTLY should be more highly rated. It's not the most exciting business but is a consistent performer that has proven resilience through the cycle -KGH should trade at a premium, as it has done historically, due to its higher growth proven buy and build model - I also think over time the upside from degearing the balance sheet will also be material which is less a factor for Gateley Still see a route to 300p+ on these in the short-medium term.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: According to London Stock Exchange website, trades were going through at 180p+ until about 3.50pm. And then after that there were a number of bigger trades that went through and over the last 40 mins of trading that drove the price down. But not massive trades, it looks like less than 100k shares in total, which isn't much in the context of a £160m mcap business. But I'm guessing there may be more selling to come behind that, hence the drop. But (in the absence of any actual news) seems to be the classic illiquid microcap getting hit disproportionately by pretty marginal selling. On twitter / X there is some healthy debate around the buy and build model (which I am comfortable with having looked at in detail, and think builds value long term), the debt levels (again I'm comfortable) and the weak backdrop in UK legal services (fair point but think overstated given GTLY today and last trading statement). I think some folk underestimate the cashflow the underlying business generates, especially with capex due to come down materially now their office refit is complete. Either one should take into account the significant growth the buy and build model generates, whilst critiquing the use of cash for M&A. OR one should consider the organic growth which is much more modest - but in this case look at underlying cash generation excl M&A. Some people out there penalise this stock BOTH for the spend on M&A, AND whilst criticising the stock for low growth excluding M&A - overly harsh in my view. But anyway this debate has been on going for a while, couldn't find anything new today... Lets see what tomorrow brings...

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: F15: How do you figure / calculate organic growth being negative? Overall they've said they'll do £162m this year vs £150 last year. Y/E is end April 2025. Of the incremental £12m I make from M&A: - IBB Law, approx c.£2m (less than 1 month of the reported £23m revenue). Completed early April 2025 - Thrusfields, approx c.£7m (7.5 months of reported £11.2m revenue). Completed mid Sept 2024 - St James Law and Baines Wilson c.£1m (maybe 2 months of reported £6.5, revenue). Not sure when completed but announce early May 2023, ie 10-11 months will fall in FY24, so only an incremental 1-2 months in FY25 vs FY24 - Convex JV is small and accounted for using equity method, ie the revenues won't be consolidated so not applicable to revenue calculations AFAIK So I make about £10m incremental revenue max from M&A in FY25, with about £2m from organic growth. Which is 1-2% organic growth. Actually it should be higher than this, as they normally expect about 20% revenue churn from new acquisitions (and they state this), so it may be more like £8m from M&A and £4m from organic growth, ie 2-3% organic growth. I'd say 'modest' is probably an appropriate term to describe this level of growth. For FY26 they are currently forecast to do £193m revenue, which is £31m incremental to FY25. Similar logic says: - £21m from IBB Law, £4m from Thursfield max. £25m total - Birket Long maybe £12.5m incremental (completion mid June 2025, total annual revenue £14.7m) Total incremental from M&A of £37m, which does imply a reduction of max £5-6m. BUT applying similar 20% revenue churn to M&A, it gets you to £30m from M&A and again a £1-2m incremental from organic. They do actually say in the RNS about Birkett Long that it brings their annualised revenue to 'over £200m' which possibly implies forecasts for FY26 are a little conservative currently and would imply continued 3% ish organic growth... The announcement was in May so of course it assumes things haven't got a chunk worse in the month or two since then. On debt, they will have about £75m net debt currently after Birkett Long payment, vs forecast £48.5m EBITDA for FY26. ie leverage of about 1.5x; still a decent amount of headroom, and they will generate cash through the year, especially now their office refit is complete. Happy to be taken to task on any of the above! Of course I'd love organic growth to be higher, and think it will be when macro environment improves. But, respectfully, I don't think you are characterising the business correctly in terms of both the growth profile and the level of debt.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Doesn't take into account the 20% churn they expect from acquisitions. I think since listing they have had one year of negative organic growth (-3% FY21, ie Covid, creditable performance IMHO), and one year of flat growth (-0.1% in FY23); the rest have shown organic growth. Admittedly the growth rate is lower today compared to the double digit organic growth they were doing pre-covid; but of course you need to take into account the weaker economic backdrop. They also exited some smaller non-core activities in 2023 (and probably at other points also). My view is the organic growth will pick up when the economic backdrop improves as M&A work and residential property work has been subdued now for a while. And besides, that they've tripled their revenues and profits since listing, whilst only increasing their share count by about 15%, is good evidence their buy and build model works... Net debt is only up about £60m (£15m to £75m) over that time, whilst EBITDA is up about £37m (£48m FY26 vs £11m in FY19). And they've been paying a divi over that period also. Hey ho, different views are what makes a market I guess...

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: TBH I agree with you in general about buy and builds, and you are right to ask the question re organic growth and debt (and interest income). I'm comfortable on all these points. Would argue the unravelling has already happened with this stock back in 2022 when it went from 400p to 150p. It was a) overrated and b) getting too much credit for the buy and build model and c) traded on a big premium to Gateley. As I've argued I think the opposite is true now at the current valuation on all three fronts. I'm up a fair chunk on my holding even after the pull back in the last few days, but think there is still a lot more to go for. In due course I suspect the CEO will want out, and suspect this will be taken private. Private Equity loves a buy and build, and will value the consistency of their revenues / cash generation more than the lack of high organic growth.

data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: "An attractive and undervalued regional consolidator" - initiation report freely accessible here: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/an-attractive-and-undervalued-regional-consolidator Knights’ FY25 results illustrate the power of its business model to attract high-quality legal professionals across the UK, both organically and through selective acquisitions. FY25 revenues rose 8% to £162m, with operating leverage driving Adj. PBT up 11% and margin up 40bps to 17.3%. Investment in offices and acquisitions, along with encouraging current trading, underpins our forecasts for profitable growth. Yet the stock is trading on only c.5x cal 2026 PER and hence the shares are well below our 230p fair value. We also examine the strength of its differentiated “corporatised law” business model. As an active consolidator in the premium regional legal market, Knights has funded over 20 acquisitions in the past 12 years, culminating in group revenues rising 8% to £162m in FY25 and £200m+ in FY26E (a 13-year CAGR of 27%). Good pricing discipline and a focus on operational excellence has seen average revenues per fee-earner rise 12% and underlying PBT margins rose 40bps to 17.3%. In our view, Knights offers a compelling mix of organic and acquisitive growth. Yet, its valuation is at a significant discount to peers and its historic trading range. Trading on only c.5x cal 2026 PER and offering a c.16% cal FCF yield (pre-acquisitions) we see scope for a significant rerating.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Organic growth lacklustre in FY25 for sure, although FY25 was in line, and forecasts maintained for FY26 which is good news. Equity Dev are forecasting 5% organic growth for the coming year though, and a few things pointing to better performance here - better recruitment and retention of fee earners, and organically are opening an office in Cardiff which I don't think they have done previously. And they're basically 5 months into FY26 already given the late release of results, so they should have decent visibility of trading ytd already... Did anyone listen to the investor call? Not on their website yet... I still think the valuation here is silly, even given the lack of growth last year. FY28 forecasts are for £47m operating profit, and will have paid off essentially all contingent consideration by then, so net debt will be about £55m. Should be trading at 7-8x EBIT in my view (v conservatively), which would be EV £330-375m, Mcap of £275-320m, and share price at least double where we are now. Plus a 3-4% divi yield while you wait...

data.content: *** Investor Presentation video recording (FY Results) - see link below *** David Beech (CEO) and Kate Lewis (CFO) of Knights Group Holdings conducted an Investor Presentation following publication of their FY25 Full Year results for the period ended 30th April 2025. Management discussed highlights of the period, which included strategic progress driving double digit profit growth. The team provided a detailed financial and operational overview, highlighting the recruitment momentum and operational excellence which positions Knights well for future organic growth. Management discussed the execution of their value-accretive acquisition strategy including the largest acquisition to date, and then answered a range of questions submitted by viewers. The full video has been divided into chapters, as below: 0:00:03 Introduction to Knights 0:03:10 Full Year Overview 0:07:04 Financial Review 0:21:19 Operational Review 0:45:10 Questions & Answers Link to full presentation: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/knights-group-fy-results-investor-presentation-video-18-september-2025

data.author: losecontrol
data.content: Why the 10p rise today? Not complaining at all just can’t see any specific reason for this big jump.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Was about to ask the same thing! They did announce on their website yesterday they've awarded 31 training contracts to some graduates / juniors, which I guess is a positive indicator of organic growth, although surely that's is not that material. Also saw this re their Sheffield office: https://www.thestar.co.uk/business/knights-sheffield-office-celebrates-first-year-with-ps363m-in-deals-and-award-recognition-5342506 The other thing (which I've pointed out before) is if you look at a share chart, after getting above the recent high of c.200p there's isn't any resistance levels all the way up to 250+ ish I think. And possibly 300p+. Although I'm not a technicals guy (anyone else on here that is want to have a better stab?) and kinda hate myself for reverting to this as an explanation for a share price move! But it does feel like this share has been testing this 190-200p level for a while and seems to have FINALLY broken out, and to my untrained eye the chart looks pretty bullish. The only other things I can think would be an analyst releasing a new note or upgrading forecasts, but I've not seen anything. Or an institutional seller cleared / a new buyer emerged but can't see any particularly big trades recently.

data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: "Delivering on its strategic ambitions" - new research with video summary freely accessible here: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/delivering-on-its-strategic-ambitions Knights’ H126 trading update illustrates the power of its position as the leading consolidator in the premium, regional legal market. Knights’ H126 revenues rose an impressive 30% to £103.2m as a return to organic growth of 3% was complemented by the recent strategic acquisitions of IBB Law, Birkett Long, Rix & Kay and Le Gros Solicitors. These acquisitions are all integrating well, with working capital benefits coming through under Knights’ ownership. From this strong performance, management is confident in achieving FY26E expectations. Whilst Knights’ share price has risen 16% in the past two months, it still only trades on 6x cal 2026 PER, a significant discount to peers and its historic trading range. In our view, Knights offers a compelling mix of organic and acquisitive growth, with net financial debt / EBITDA only 1.4x (FY26E). We see scope for a significant rerating and reiterate our 230p/ share fair value estimate.
data.thread_title: "Delivering on its strategic ambitions" - new research

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: This has dropped back c.20% from the highs now. Not sure why other than market malaise? Trading update last week showed everything is still in line and despite the uncertainty around the budget etc the business is still growing and performing as expected. As ever would hope organic growth improves from 3% in H1 to the 5% that they guided to for the full year a short time ago... This is now trading on 5.8x EV/EBIT, 6.4 PE, for a growing business that is performing well and that throws off cash. Although net debt has increased, they have paid off a substantial amount of deferred consideration in the last few years, as of now only £17m ish remains. Balance sheet well below 2x geared now. Interesting to think that in 2021 this share was trading at 400p ish. It's now less than half that, despite revenue (£100m to £200m) and operating profit (£20m to 40m) having doubled in the period since... I still think this gets to 320-370p over the next 2-3 years - and that's not assuming anything other than hitting their forecasts and a modest rerating to 7-8x EV/EBIT. Plus you'll get 16p+ in dividends over that period. I actually think this could prove pretty conservative as in reality they will continue to acquire / integrate businesses and will be bigger / more profitable than forecasts currently suggest by that point in time...
data.thread_title: RE: "Delivering on its strategic ambitions" - new research

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Now down over 25% from the highs, and no news except in line trading statement. Trading on about 5.4x 12m fwd PE. Only thing I can think is weak sentiment to UK focused stocks after the fumbled budget. Or just a bit of technical pressure with Octopus reducing their stake. Looking at the register, could do with a few more 'blue chip' institutional investors in this. For a company of this size (£130m+ mcap) you would expect more interest. Used to be absolutely loved by the market, I guess fund managers have long memories after being burned by this in 2021. Will probably continue to drift until their half year results on 12th Jan as doubt there will be any news flow over the xmas period. Probably a good time to top up if I can get through the next couple of weeks results etc unscathed!
data.thread_title: Any thoughts on why it's dropped?

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Gateley H1 (to end Oct) showed organic growth of 10.9% in legal services. Shows it can be done even in this market. Knights cand and should be growing faster organically than it is. Gateley legal did 10.9% organic in H1 was up from 3.9% in 12m to April 2025, and 2.1% in 6m to October 2024, so accelerating trend. They also said "We estimate that pre-Budget transactional inertia impacted H1 revenue by circa £3m, which if delivered in H1 would have resulted in H1 margins consistent with full year expectations.  We expect this inertia to unwind in H2". SO this implies another 3% organic growth which should be deferred to H2. I believe Knights has more exposure to transactional cases so hopefully will also benefit from this unwind going into H2 post budget. H1 results 12th Jan....

data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: "Successful strategy deserves a higher rating" - link to (freely accessible) new research here: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/successful-strategy-deserves-a-higher-rating Knights’ H126 results were as announced at its update in November and illustrate the power of its position as the leading consolidator in the premium, regional legal market. Revenues rose an impressive 30%, including a return to organic growth of 2.6%, and Adj. PBT rose 12.5%, despite absorbing increased national insurance costs and investing in AI, led by a new CTO. Operating cashflow conversion has been excellent and momentum has continued into H226, hence management is confident in achieving FY26E expectations. Yet Knights still only trades on 6.5x cal 2026 PER and under 6x cal 2027 PER. Given the successful H126 and positive outlook we raise our Fair Value/per share from 230p to 255p, equivalent to c.8x cal 2027 PER.
data.thread_title: "Successful strategy deserves a higher rating" - new research

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Solid results, no real surprises to the upside or down. Looks like they might be marginally ahead of expectations for FY on rev / profit, and maybe will beat on cash / debt. Organic growth at 3% when it should really be higher, expecting 5% for the full year so H2 should be better but they didn't give anything quantitative about H2 trading other than that it was building on momentum and in line with expectations. Gateley growing faster organically, proves it can be done if mgmt get it right. Hopefully the lower staff churn and new recruits will start to deliver and we'll see an acceleration. As ever there are a few wrinkles - high exceptionals in the period (M&A related), organic growth a bit low (see above) but importantly is positive number now, capex still higher than where it should be in my view for this sort of business given they have finished their refurb programme now, and margins trajectory could be better but mainly impacted by things outside their control. Having said that I still think this business is an absolute steal at 6.5x PE. Hoping that they have an H2 without any M&A so that there is a clean period of organic growth, cash generation and deleveraging of the balance sheet. Only 3.5 months left in their FY, so they should have high visibility to the FY numbers, and can get on to the front foot for FY27 come April. Organic growth plus stabilisation / improvement of margins, plus cash generation plus a few more sensible deals... And sentiment to this could finally begin to turn more positive; rerating to 8-10x PE is eminently achievable to my mind in the near term - 240-300p. 12x would not be an outrageous rating to expect on continued delivery, which would be 350-400p longer term.
data.thread_title: RE: "Successful strategy deserves a higher rating" - new research

data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: David Beech (CEO), Kate Lewis (CFO) and James Sheridan (M&A Director) ran investors through key details of their Interim results for the six months ended 31st October 2025. Highlights included a strong first half with underlying revenue up 30%, staff churn back to pre-Covid levels and a return to organic growth of c.3%. The team provided a detailed financial and operational review, and discussed the strategic scaling of the platform for growth. Management highlighted enhanced infrastructure investment and AI initiatives, commented on current trading & outlook, and answered a range of questions submitted by viewers. The full video of the presentation has been divided into chapters, as below: 0:00:03 Introduction to Knights 0:04:27 Half Year Overview 0:08:36 Financial Review 0:25:08 Operational Review 0:45:50 Questions & Answers Link to full video: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/knights-group-hy-results-investor-presentation-video-14-january-2026

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: TBH I agree with you in general about buy and builds, and you are right to ask the question re organic growth and debt (and interest income). I'm comfortable on all these points. Would argue the unravelling has already happened with this stock back in 2022 when it went from 400p to 150p. It was a) overrated and b) getting too much credit for the buy and build model and c) traded on a big premium to Gateley. As I've argued I think the opposite is true now at the current valuation on all three fronts. I'm up a fair chunk on my holding even after the pull back in the last few days, but think there is still a lot more to go for. In due course I suspect the CEO will want out, and suspect this will be taken private. Private Equity loves a buy and build, and will value the consistency of their revenues / cash generation more than the lack of high organic growth.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: One could argue they should be deploying their cash against a) paying down debt a little, and b) doing a buyback at these SP levels, but I think mgmt are committed to their strategy of building something that is greater than the sum of its parts. Up to them to deliver. I back them to do so, and think they have demonstrated historically that they can do so.

data.content: I think the reason dividend is preferred over debt reduction and /or buyback, is that it provides a substantial income to the insiders

data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: "An attractive and undervalued regional consolidator" - initiation report freely accessible here: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/an-attractive-and-undervalued-regional-consolidator Knights’ FY25 results illustrate the power of its business model to attract high-quality legal professionals across the UK, both organically and through selective acquisitions. FY25 revenues rose 8% to £162m, with operating leverage driving Adj. PBT up 11% and margin up 40bps to 17.3%. Investment in offices and acquisitions, along with encouraging current trading, underpins our forecasts for profitable growth. Yet the stock is trading on only c.5x cal 2026 PER and hence the shares are well below our 230p fair value. We also examine the strength of its differentiated “corporatised law” business model. As an active consolidator in the premium regional legal market, Knights has funded over 20 acquisitions in the past 12 years, culminating in group revenues rising 8% to £162m in FY25 and £200m+ in FY26E (a 13-year CAGR of 27%). Good pricing discipline and a focus on operational excellence has seen average revenues per fee-earner rise 12% and underlying PBT margins rose 40bps to 17.3%. In our view, Knights offers a compelling mix of organic and acquisitive growth. Yet, its valuation is at a significant discount to peers and its historic trading range. Trading on only c.5x cal 2026 PER and offering a c.16% cal FCF yield (pre-acquisitions) we see scope for a significant rerating.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Organic growth lacklustre in FY25 for sure, although FY25 was in line, and forecasts maintained for FY26 which is good news. Equity Dev are forecasting 5% organic growth for the coming year though, and a few things pointing to better performance here - better recruitment and retention of fee earners, and organically are opening an office in Cardiff which I don't think they have done previously. And they're basically 5 months into FY26 already given the late release of results, so they should have decent visibility of trading ytd already... Did anyone listen to the investor call? Not on their website yet... I still think the valuation here is silly, even given the lack of growth last year. FY28 forecasts are for £47m operating profit, and will have paid off essentially all contingent consideration by then, so net debt will be about £55m. Should be trading at 7-8x EBIT in my view (v conservatively), which would be EV £330-375m, Mcap of £275-320m, and share price at least double where we are now. Plus a 3-4% divi yield while you wait...

data.author: Florence141414
data.content: I emailed the company last week regarding the Supreme Court ruling. Just to make sure they have no exposure as there was one paragraph in the results that was slightly ambiguous (to my untrained eye anyway) as to whether they engaged in litigation funding. This was the email: ‘I just have a quick question regarding yesterday's supreme court ruling. I notice the following paragraph in your recent year end results.... Certain contingent fee arrangements are undertaken on a partially funded basis. In such arrangements, the funded portion of fees is not contingent on the successful outcome of the litigation and in these instances the revenue is recognised up to the amount of fees that the Group is entitled to bill for services performed to date based on contracted rates. The remaining consideration is variable and conditional on the successful resolution of the litigation. The variable consideration is recognised over the duration of the matter and included in revenue based on the expected amount recoverable only to the extent that it is highly probable that the amount recognised will not be subject to significant reversal when the uncertainty is resolved at that point in time. Do you expect that these arrangements will be effected by yesterday's ruling?’ This Morning I received the following reply from the CFO which I found very helpful. So thought I’d share for the benefit of others: ‘Good morning Further to your email below, the ruling by the Supreme Court will not have any impact on our business. We do not have any funding agreements within the business that fall into the category covered by the ruling. Many thanks Kate’

data.author: bangrak
data.content: We've identified 30% of real estate exposure and pessimistically removed 35% from earnings based on consensus of 5 analysts in 2024 2025 and this places it on a forward PE of 5.6 2025. This is still cheap v piers 8-19-9, 65% below professional & commercial services average and this is assuming that not one single property transaction takes place, and they do not get any benefit from corporate law acquisitions and international business/insolvency aka "very very bad". I think that's too prudent but still shows considerable value. I think it is worth nearer an 8-9 on a eps of 21p, the consensus of 5 analysts is 162p. Mid 2024 things will be different the charts for inflation and interest rates align there. For me, the risk is minimal, and the reward is high.

If you compare to the overall market there is a whole host of decent companies around now with P/E in the 5-10 range.

data.author: Dartron
data.content: I sold my Knights shares before and after the results, after a fantastic 30% rise over Christmas. https://x.com/DartronTrading/status/1745407668406173818?s=20 I just felt that there wasn't anything left in the tank from a rally perspective. I bought another small cap, which is in the position that Knights was around a year ago. Well under half of its fair value, still recovering from a few recent issues. I think that is what attracted me to Knights, being able to buy as low as the 70's. with a 50% upside. I note there was a lot more discussion on this board back at that time, have most sold out as well? I was prompted to post here today as I found this rating from Shore capital, which has a target price of 115p - and yes it was published after the latest results. TBH, I would like to buy these back, but Im not interested in paying above 115 for them after ExD. The Investors Chronical also rates these as a hold and has them on a PE of 11, which disagrees somewhat with Shore's PE of 5 even taking in to account the rise in SP. The shore article is a little contradictory expecting the shares to re rate, but the price is already above their fair value target.  I can see the 115 target on the research portal of IC, so its not a typo. The median target here is 160. I have shares that have dropped on weak earnings with higher % targets than this after they have been down graded - AFM today for example, "Analyst Calum Battersby retained his ‘buy’ recommendation and target price of 420p on the consultancy group" that is a 25% upside target after a downgrade. All makes me thinks Knights is around fair value, and not much of an income play. (AFM is not my new small cap, im stuck in there over a year). Shore Capital makes a strong case for resilient Knights Group Legal services company Knights Group (KGH) is trading on an ‘undemanding’ valuation and has scope to rerate, says Shore Capital. Analyst Jamie Murray retained his ‘buy’ recommendation and ‘fair value’ target price of 115p on the stock, which was trading at 121p on Friday. It reported ‘resilient’ first half 2024 results, which ‘highlighted that management is executing its renewed strategy to focus on organic growth’, Murray said. ‘The outlook is positive with non-cyclical legal activity showing resilience and recruitment initiatives increasing fee earner headcount,’ he explained. Although Knights is a ‘well-regarded law firm with as strong presence outside of London which enables it to win market share’, Murray said the shares trade on an ‘undemanding price/earnings target of 5x’. ‘We expect this to increase following these resilient results,’ he said. ‘If management continue to execute its new strategy focused on organic growth, we think it can rerate to a multiple more in-line with the sector.’

Basic EPS of 11.47p (FY23: 9.28p) · Strong improvement in lock up3 days to 78 (FY23: 87 days), with debtor days improving to 28 (FY23: 30 days) · Continued excellent cash conversion4 of 131% (FY23: 117%) enabling investment in growth · Net debt5 of £35.2m (30 April 23: £29.2m), after a cash outlay of £11.3m relating to acquisitions and a joint venture investment in Convex Corporate Finance Limited resulting in a reduction in banking covenant EBITDA / net debt ratio to 1.1x (30 April 2023: 1.2x) · Final dividend of 2.79p (FY23: 2.50p), giving a 9% increase in the total dividend to 4.40p (FY23: 4.03p)

data.author: EquityDevelopmen
data.content: David Beech (CEO), Kate Lewis (CFO) and James Sheridan (M&A Director) ran investors through key details of their Interim results for the six months ended 31st October 2025. Highlights included a strong first half with underlying revenue up 30%, staff churn back to pre-Covid levels and a return to organic growth of c.3%. The team provided a detailed financial and operational review, and discussed the strategic scaling of the platform for growth. Management highlighted enhanced infrastructure investment and AI initiatives, commented on current trading & outlook, and answered a range of questions submitted by viewers. The full video of the presentation has been divided into chapters, as below: 0:00:03 Introduction to Knights 0:04:27 Half Year Overview 0:08:36 Financial Review 0:25:08 Operational Review 0:45:50 Questions & Answers Link to full video: https://www.equitydevelopment.co.uk/research/knights-group-hy-results-investor-presentation-video-14-january-2026
data.thread_title: Investor Presentation video recording (HY Results) - 14th January

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Solid results, no real surprises to the upside or down. Looks like they might be marginally ahead of expectations for FY on rev / profit, and maybe will beat on cash / debt. Organic growth at 3% when it should really be higher, expecting 5% for the full year so H2 should be better but they didn't give anything quantitative about H2 trading other than that it was building on momentum and in line with expectations. Gateley growing faster organically, proves it can be done if mgmt get it right. Hopefully the lower staff churn and new recruits will start to deliver and we'll see an acceleration. As ever there are a few wrinkles - high exceptionals in the period (M&A related), organic growth a bit low (see above) but importantly is positive number now, capex still higher than where it should be in my view for this sort of business given they have finished their refurb programme now, and margins trajectory could be better but mainly impacted by things outside their control. Having said that I still think this business is an absolute steal at 6.5x PE. Hoping that they have an H2 without any M&A so that there is a clean period of organic growth, cash generation and deleveraging of the balance sheet. Only 3.5 months left in their FY, so they should have high visibility to the FY numbers, and can get on to the front foot for FY27 come April. Organic growth plus stabilisation / improvement of margins, plus cash generation plus a few more sensible deals... And sentiment to this could finally begin to turn more positive; rerating to 8-10x PE is eminently achievable to my mind in the near term - 240-300p. 12x would not be an outrageous rating to expect on continued delivery, which would be 350-400p longer term.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: This has dropped back c.20% from the highs now. Not sure why other than market malaise? Trading update last week showed everything is still in line and despite the uncertainty around the budget etc the business is still growing and performing as expected. As ever would hope organic growth improves from 3% in H1 to the 5% that they guided to for the full year a short time ago... I still think this gets to 320-370p over the next 2-3 years - and that's not assuming anything other than hitting their forecasts and a modest rerating to 7-8x EV/EBIT. Plus you'll get 16p+ in dividends over that period. I actually think this could prove pretty conservative as in reality they will continue to acquire / integrate businesses and will be bigger / more profitable than forecasts currently suggest by that point in time...

FY25 revenues rose 8% to £162m, with operating leverage driving Adj. PBT up 11% and margin up 40bps to 17.3%. Investment in offices and acquisitions, along with encouraging current trading, underpins our forecasts for profitable growth. Yet the stock is trading on only c.5x cal 2026 PER and hence the shares are well below our 230p fair value. We also examine the strength of its differentiated “corporatised law” business model. As an active consolidator in the premium regional legal market, Knights has funded over 20 acquisitions in the past 12 years, culminating in group revenues rising 8% to £162m in FY25 and £200m+ in FY26E (a 13-year CAGR of 27%). Good pricing discipline and a focus on operational excellence has seen average revenues per fee-earner rise 12% and underlying PBT margins rose 40bps to 17.3%. In our view, Knights offers a compelling mix of organic and acquisitive growth. Yet, its valuation is at a significant discount to peers and its historic trading range. Trading on only c.5x cal 2026 PER and offering a c.16% cal FCF yield (pre-acquisitions) we see scope for a significant rerating.

data.author: TargetPractice
data.content: Doesn't take into account the 20% churn they expect from acquisitions. I think since listing they have had one year of negative organic growth (-3% FY21, ie Covid, creditable performance IMHO), and one year of flat growth (-0.1% in FY23); the rest have shown organic growth. Admittedly the growth rate is lower today compared to the double digit organic growth they were doing pre-covid; but of course you need to take into account the weaker economic backdrop. They also exited some smaller non-core activities in 2023 (and probably at other points also). My view is the organic growth will pick up when the economic backdrop improves as M&A work and residential property work has been subdued now for a while. And besides, that they've tripled their revenues and profits since listing, whilst only increasing their share count by about 15%, is good evidence their buy and build model works... Net debt is only up about £60m (£15m to £75m) over that time, whilst EBITDA is up about £37m (£48m FY26 vs £11m in FY19). And they've been paying a divi over that period also. Hey ho, different views are what makes a market I guess...
